keySentences: 3 analysts on why AI debt isn't a bubble AI companies are turning to debt markets to fund data centers.

But analysts say this new wave of bonds aren't bubbles By Niamh Rowe Share to X Share to Facebook Share to Reddit Share to Email Share to Link Getty Images / Bloomberg Tech companies are flooding bond markets to raise billions of dollars to build the infrastructure needed to power artificial intelligence.

Suggested Reading The Fed will fly blind for a second interest-rate meeting in a row Air traffic controllers who stuck around during shutdown have a serious bonus coming It‚Äôs not just you: The internet keeps breaking U.S. companies have issued more than $200 billion worth of investment grade (IG) corporate bonds this year to fund AI-related infrastructure projects ‚Äî about 13% of total IG issuance, as of end-October.
Collectively, they've raised $121 billion of IG debt this year, Bank of America analysts wrote in a November 17 note.

Around $75 billion of this was issued in September and October alone ‚Äî amid two interest rate cuts ‚Äî which is more than double the sector's average annual issuance during the prior decade, BofA data shows.
The borrowing is expected to push total U.S. corporate bond issuance to a record $1.8 trillion next year, according to JP Morgan.
Magnificent Seven stocks have fallen about 7% in November, according to an exchange-traded fund that tracks their performance.
Cut to Monday, however, when Amazon sold of $15 billion of notes, and orders fell an unusually steep 40% once pricing was revealed.
In September, amid the deluge of new debt, bonds issued by Amazon, Microsoft, Meta, and Alphabet saw their spread over Treasuries widen towards 80 basis points from around 50, according to BofA data.
The spread on its bonds have widened by 48 basis points since September.
Its $3.25 billion, 5-year bond, is trading 104 basis points over Treasuries ‚Äî doubling since September 15.
The spread on Oracle‚Äôs five-year CDS has more than doubled since September, according to ICE Data Services, to the highest cost since 2023.

Robert Schiffman, senior credit analyst at Bloomberg Intelligence, refers to hyperscalers as the "Mount Rushmore" of credits with ‚Äúmassive financial flexibility‚Äù to add hundreds of billions of dollars of debt due to their large balance sheets and historically tight margins.
In their third quarter earnings for 2025, these companies'  trailing twelve-month cash flow from operating activities ranged from $30 billion to almost $340 billion.
So, while Big Tech's AI-related capex has been jaw-dropping ‚Äî hitting $113.4 billion in the third quarter, up 75% year-over-year ‚Äî cash flow has remained strong.
With a BBB credit rating, the cloud company has more than $104 billion in outstanding debt, while its free cash flow turned negative in 2025, falling to its lowest level in over two decades.
For example, well over half of U.S. tech IG issuance in H2 has come from issuers rated A and above," HSBC multi-asset analysts wrote in an investor note on Monday.
"Aggregate capex to free cash flow is nowhere near the levels of the late 1990s yet,‚Äù they said in reference to the dot-com bubble that burst in 2000.
What's more, this year, U.S. IG spreads have touched their narrowest levels in 15 years.
Stocks in hyperscalers Meta, Alphabet and Microsoft are up more than 347%, 230% and 109% since 2023, respectively.
Morgan‚Äôs estimates that AI needs $650 billion in annual revenue ‚Äúto make the math work."
For example, Nvidia‚Äôs data center revenue is now running around $39-41 billion annually, more than doubling year-over-year in some recent quarters.
AWS has reached $123 billion in annualized revenue.
Citi Research forecasts $780 billion in annual AI revenues by 2030.
Morgan Stanley research estimates a $1.5 trillion funding shortfall for AI data centers by 2028.
Sign me up Getty Images / Bloomberg Tech companies are flooding bond markets to raise billions of dollars to build the infrastructure needed to power artificial intelligence.

Canaccord Genuity Remains Bullish on IREN Limited (IREN) Following Q3 2025 Results Carol Gauthier/Shutterstock.com On November 10, 2025, The Fly reported that Canaccord Genuity increased its price target on IREN Limited (NASDAQ:IREN) from $42 to $70, while reiterating a ‚ÄúBuy‚Äù rating.
Meanwhile, IREN Limited (NASDAQ:IREN) reported its Q3 2025 results on November 6, 2025.
For the quarter, the company recorded $240.3 million in revenue, up 28% sequentially and 355% year-over-year.
Adjusted EBITDA came in at $91.7 million, up 3,568% YoY.
Once GPU expansion is complete, the Microsoft deal could generate $1.94 billion in annual recurring revenue.
Furthermore, IREN Limited (NASDAQ:IREN) plans to expand from 23,000 GPUs to 140,000 by the end of 2026 as it continues to aggressively scale its GPU infrastructure.
Microsoft will partially fund capital expenditures with a 20% upfront prepayment.
The company has already secured $400 million in additional funding for the expansion.

The latest wave of AI-focused partnerships, including deep integration with Microsoft 365 and enhanced agent governance, reinforces ServiceNow's efforts to stay ahead in enterprise automation, but doesn't materially change the fact that short-term performance remains closely tied to execution in these highly competitive markets.

Among recent announcements, the Microsoft integration stands out as especially relevant: ServiceNow AI Control Tower and unified agentic workflows are now more seamlessly embedded across Microsoft 365 platforms.
ServiceNow‚Äôs outlook points to $20.3 billion in revenue and $3.3 billion in earnings by 2028.
Achieving this would require 18.9% annual revenue growth and a $1.6 billion increase in earnings from the current $1.7 billion.

Recently, Microsoft‚Äôs stock has pulled back, with a drop of 7.4% over the past week and 9.3% in the last month, but it‚Äôs still up 12.8% year-to-date and 14.1% over the last year.
Based on six key valuation checks, Microsoft scores 5 out of 6 for being undervalued.
Microsoft delivered 14.1% returns over the last year.

Approach 1: Microsoft Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis The Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) model estimates a company‚Äôs intrinsic value by projecting all future cash flows it can generate and discounting those back to today‚Äôs value.
For Microsoft, the DCF model uses its latest reported Free Cash Flow (FCF) of $89.4 Billion.
Analysts forecast that this figure will continue to climb, with projections reaching $206.2 Billion in 2030.

While analysts typically provide estimates only for the next five years, further forecasts such as those out to 2035 are extrapolated using industry methods, giving a long-term perspective on Microsoft‚Äôs growth potential.
Based on these calculations, the DCF model assigns Microsoft an intrinsic value of $609.57 per share.
With the model‚Äôs intrinsic discount indicating the stock is 22.5% below its estimated fair value, this suggests Microsoft is currently undervalued.
Result: UNDERVALUED Our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) analysis suggests Microsoft is undervalued by 22.5%.
Track this in your watchlist or portfolio , or discover 918 more undervalued stocks based on cash flows .
MSFT Discounted Cash Flow as at Nov 2025 Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for Microsoft.

Story Continues Approach 2: Microsoft Price vs Earnings (PE Ratio) The Price-to-Earnings (PE) ratio is one of the most widely used valuation tools for profitable companies like Microsoft, as it relates a company‚Äôs share price to its earnings performance.
This multiple is especially meaningful for established businesses where profits are both significant and expected to grow consistently.
Investors often look to the PE ratio as a quick gauge of whether a stock is priced attractively relative to its profitability.
For context, Microsoft currently trades at a PE ratio of 33.5x.
This is slightly below the Software industry average of 29.0x and just under the peer group average of 34.0x, positioning Microsoft in line with expectations for leading tech stocks.

However, looking beyond simple averages, Simply Wall St introduces the ‚ÄúFair Ratio,‚Äù a more tailored benchmark that weighs Microsoft‚Äôs specific attributes, such as forecasted earnings growth, profit margins, market dominance, and risk profile.
For Microsoft, the Fair Ratio is calculated at a much higher 57.2x, reflecting both its robust fundamentals and future growth runway.
With Microsoft‚Äôs PE of 33.5x significantly below its Fair Ratio of 57.2x, the stock appears undervalued on this metric.
Result: UNDERVALUED NasdaqGS:MSFT PE Ratio as at Nov 2025 PE ratios tell one story, but what if the real opportunity lies elsewhere?
Discover 1420 companies where insiders are betting big on explosive growth .

For example, while some investors expect Microsoft‚Äôs fair value to reach $700 based on aggressive AI-driven growth and margin expansion, others see a more cautious outcome near $360 given industry headwinds and execution risks.
By exploring Narratives, you can join millions of users in making better, more individualized decisions backed by your own view of Microsoft‚Äôs future.

For Microsoft, however, we'll make it really easy for you with previews of two leading Microsoft Narratives: üêÇ Microsoft Bull Case Fair Value: $500.00 Current Undervaluation: 5.6% Revenue Growth Assumption: 6.75% Warns that Microsoft's current high valuation may be overly optimistic, given headwinds such as a shrinking PC market, increased Mac adoption in enterprises, and underperformance of the Xbox in console sales.

üêª Microsoft Bear Case Fair Value: $423.14 Current Overvaluation: 11.6% Revenue Growth Assumption: 10% Emphasizes strong catalysts like AI integration across Office and Azure, continued cloud growth, gaming expansion through Activision, and recurring enterprise software revenues.
NasdaqGS:MSFT Community Fair Values as at Nov 2025 This article by Simply Wall St is general in nature.

So as billions of dollars flow into chip makers, data centers and startups, the question on everyone‚Äôs mind looms ‚Äî are we in an AI bubble?
Gates was quick to clarify that not all bubbles are created equal in an Oct. 28 interview on CNBC .
